docs.lead_paragraph: For public officials interested in running for mayor, there seems to be a ritual these days of presenting policy speeches at breakfasts run by the Association for a Better New York. And today, it was United States Representative Anthony D. Weiner's turn.

headline.main: Weiner's Vision of Healthier Days Ahead

docs.abstract: Representative Anthony D. Weiner is the latest of the presumed candidates for mayor in 2009 to address a breakfast run by the Association for a Better New York.
docs.snippet: Representative Anthony D. Weiner is the latest of the presumed candidates for mayor in 2009 to address a breakfast run by the Association for a Better New York.

docs.lead_paragraph: A chart on Sunday about improvements in Malawi’s agricultural production, using erroneous information from a study by researchers at Imperial College London and Michigan State University, misstated the size of recent corn harvests. (Because of an editing error, the article also included the wrong figures.) The increase in production was in millions of metric tons, not billions. (Estimates show that corn production rose to 2.7 million metric tons in 2006 and 3.4 million in 2007 from 1.2 million in 2005.).

docs.lead_paragraph: A study says that at least 46,600 children along the Gulf Coast are still struggling with mental health problems and other serious aftereffects of hurricanes in 2005.
docs.snippet: A study says that at least 46,600 children along the Gulf Coast are still struggling with mental health problems and other serious aftereffects of hurricanes in 2005.

docs.lead_paragraph: First-time claims for unemployment benefits fell by 15,000 last week, but a four-week moving average of new filings was the highest in more than two years.
docs.snippet: First-time claims for unemployment benefits fell by 15,000 last week, but a four-week moving average of new filings was the highest in more than two years.

docs.lead_paragraph: Barack Obama is storing up trouble for health reformers by suggesting that there is something nasty about plans that “force every American to buy health care.”
docs.snippet: Barack Obama is storing up trouble for health reformers by suggesting that there is something nasty about plans that “force every American to buy health care.”

docs.lead_paragraph: An article on Wednesday about health care proposals offered by some presidential candidates referred incorrectly to Massachusetts residents who might be exempt from the state's mandated health insurance plan. The state has estimated that up to 20 percent of all uninsured residents could be exempt -- not 20 percent of all residents. (The percentage of residents who have no insurance is estimated at between 6 and 10 percent.)
